[[File:Eeg alpha.svg|thumb|300px|alt=Single lead EEG readout|One second sample of an [[EEG]] [[alpha wave]] recording. This wave occurs at [[frequency|frequencies]] similar to the mu wave, although the alpha wave is detected over a different part of the brain.]] [[Image:Motor cortex.PNG|thumb|alt=Left motor cortex highlighted on the brain|The left [[motor cortex]], or [[Brodmann area 4|BA4]], is highlighted in green on this left [[Lateral (anatomy)|lateral]] view of the brain. This is the area over which mu waves are detected [[wikt:bilateral|bilateral]]ly.]]
'''Mu waves''', also known as '''mu rhythms''', comb or wicket rhythms, arciform rhythms, or [[sensorimotor rhythm]]s, are synchronized patterns of electrical activity involving large numbers of [[neuron]]s, probably of the [[Pyramidal cell|pyramidal]] type, in the part of the brain that controls voluntary movement.<ref name=Amzica /> These patterns as measured by [[electroencephalography]] (EEG), [[magnetoencephalography]] (MEG), or [[electrocorticography]] (ECoG), repeat at a frequency of 7.5–12.5 (and primarily 9–11) [[Hertz|Hz]], and are most prominent when the body is physically at rest.<ref name=Amzica>{{cite book|title=Niedermeyer's Electroencephalography: Basic Principles, Clinical Applications, and Related Fields|year=2010|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=978-0-7817-8942-4|pages=33–63|author=Amzica, Florin|edition=6th|author2=Fernando Lopes da Silva|editor=Schomer, Donald L. |editor2=Fernando Lopes da Silva|chapter=Celluluar Substrates of Brain Rhythms}}</ref> Unlike the [[alpha wave]], which occurs at a similar frequency over the resting [[visual cortex]] at the back of the scalp, the mu wave is found over the [[motor cortex]], in a band approximately from ear to ear. A person suppresses mu wave patterns when he or she performs a motor action or, with practice, when he or she visualizes performing a motor action. This suppression is called [[wikt:desynchronization|desynchronization]] of the wave because EEG wave forms are caused by large numbers of neurons firing in synchrony. The mu wave is even suppressed when one observes another person performing a motor action or an abstract motion with biological characteristics. Researchers such as [[Vilayanur S. Ramachandran|V. S. Ramachandran]] and colleagues have suggested that this is a sign that the [[mirror neuron system]] is involved in mu wave suppression,<ref name=Oberman>{{cite journal |last=Oberman |first=Lindsay M. |author2= Edward M. Hubbarda |author3=Eric L. Altschulera |author4=Vilayanur S. Ramachandran |author5= Jaime A. Pineda |title=EEG evidence for mirror neuron dysfunction in autism spectrum disorders |journal=Cognitive Brain Research |date=July 2005 |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=190–198 |doi= 10.1016/j.cogbrainres.2005.01.014 |pmid=15993757 }}</ref><ref name=Pineda3 /> although others disagree.<ref name=Churchland>{{cite book |last=Churchland |first=Patricia |title=Braintrust: What Neuroscience Tells Us About Morality|year=2011|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, NJ|isbn=978-0-691-13703-2|page=156}}</ref>
The mu wave is of interest to a variety of scholars. Scientists who study [[neural development]] are interested in the details of the development of the mu wave in infancy and childhood and its role in learning.<ref name=Nystrom>{{cite journal|last=Nyström|first=Pär|author2=Ljunghammar, Therese |author3=Rosander, Kerstin |author4= Von Hofsten, Claes |title=Using mu rhythm desynchronization to measure mirror neuron activity in infants|journal=Developmental Science|year=2011|volume=14|issue=2|pages=327–335|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2010.00979.x|pmid=22213903}}</ref> Since a group of researchers believe that [[autism spectrum disorder]] (ASD) is strongly influenced by an altered mirror neuron system<ref name=Oberman /><ref name=Bernier>{{cite journal|last=Bernier|first=R.|author2=Dawson, G. |author3=Webb, S. |author4= Murias, M. |title=EEG mu rhythm and imitation impairments in individuals with autism spectrum disorder|journal=Brain and Cognition|year= 2007|volume=64|issue=3|pages=228–237|doi=10.1016/j.bandc.2007.03.004|pmid=17451856|pmc=2709976}}</ref><ref name=Williams /> and that mu wave suppression is a downstream indication of mirror neuron activity,<ref name=Pineda3 /> many of these scientists have kindled a more popular interest in investigating the mu wave in people with ASD. Assorted investigators are also in the process of using mu waves to develop a new technology: the [[brain-computer interface]] (BCI). With the emergence of BCI systems, clinicians hope to give the severely physically disabled population new methods of communication and a means to manipulate and navigate their environments.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1>{{cite book|title=Niedermeyer's Electroencephalography: Basic Principles, Clinical Applications, and Related Fields|year=2010|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=978-0-7817-8942-4|pages=1227–1236|author=Pfurtscheller, Gert|edition=6th|author2=Christa Neuper|editor=Schomer, Donald L. |editor2= Fernando H. Lopes da Silva|chapter=EEG-Based Brain-Computer Interfaces}}</ref>
==Mirror neurons==
The [[mirror neuron system]] consists of a class of [[neuron]]s that was first studied in the 1990s in [[macaque monkey]]s.<ref name=Williams>{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=Justin H.G.|author2=Waiter, Gordon D. |author3=Gilchrist, Anne |author4=Perrett, David I. |author5=Murray, Alison D. |author6= Whiten, Andrew |title=Neural mechanisms of imitation and 'mirror neuron' functioning in autistic spectrum disorder|journal=Neuropsychologia|date=1 January 2006|volume=44|issue=4|pages=610–621|doi=10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2005.06.010|pmid=16140346|url=http://culture.st-and.ac.uk/whiten/docs/NeuralMechanisms.pdf}}</ref> Studies have found sets of neurons that fire when these monkeys perform simple tasks and also when the monkeys view others performing the same simple tasks.<ref name="di Pellegrino">{{cite journal|last=di Pellegrino|first=G.|author2=Fadiga, L. |author3=Fogassi, L. |author4=Gallese, F. |author5= Rizzolatti, G. |title=Understanding motor events: A neurophysiological study |journal=Experimental Brain Research |year=1992 |volume=91 |issue=1|pages=176–180 |pmid=1301372 |doi= 10.1007/bf00230027}}</ref> This suggests they play a role in mapping others' movements into the brain without actually physically performing the movements. These sets of neurons are called mirror neurons and together make up the mirror neuron system. Mu waves are suppressed when these neurons fire, a phenomenon which allows researchers to study mirror neuron activity in humans.<ref name=Rizzolatti>{{cite journal|last=Rizzolatti|first=G|author2=Fogassi, L |author3=Gallese, V |title=Neurophysiological mechanisms underlying the understanding and imitation of action|journal=Nature Reviews. Neuroscience|date=September 2001|volume=2|issue=9|pages=661–70|pmid=11533734|doi=10.1038/35090060}}</ref> There is evidence that mirror neurons exist in humans as well as in non-human animals. The right [[fusiform gyrus]], left [[inferior parietal lobule]], right anterior [[Parietal lobe|parietal cortex]], and left [[inferior frontal gyrus]] are of particular interest.<ref name=Williams /><ref name=Marshall>{{cite journal|last=Marshall|first=Peter J.|author2=Meltzoff, Andrew N.|title=Neural mirroring systems: Exploring the EEG mu rhythm in human infancy|journal=Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience|year=2011|volume=1|issue=2|pages=110–123|doi=10.1016/j.dcn.2010.09.001|pmc=3081582|pmid=21528008}}</ref><ref name=Keuken /> Some researchers believe that mu wave suppression can be a consequence of mirror neuron activity throughout the brain, and represents a higher-level integrative processing of mirror neuron activity.<ref name=Pineda3 /> Tests in both monkeys (using invasive measuring techniques) and humans (using EEG and [[fMRI]]) have found that these mirror neurons not only fire during basic motor tasks, but also have components that deal with intention.<ref name=Sinigaglia>{{cite journal|last=Sinigaglia|first=C|author2=Rizzolatti, G|title=Through the looking glass: self and others|journal=Consciousness and Cognition|date=March 2011|volume=20|issue=1|pages=64–74|pmid=21220203|doi=10.1016/j.concog.2010.11.012}}</ref> There is evidence of an important role for mirror neurons in humans, and mu waves may represent a high level coordination of those mirror neurons.<ref name=Pineda3 />
==Development==
A fruitful conceptualization of mu waves in pediatric use is that mu wave ''suppression'' is a representation of activity going on in the world, and is detectable in the [[Frontal lobe|frontal]] and [[Parietal lobe|parietal]] networks.<ref name=Pineda3 /> A resting oscillation becomes suppressed during the observation of sensory information such as sounds or sights, usually within the [[wikt:frontoparietal|frontoparietal]] (motor) cortical region.<ref name=Pineda3 /> The mu wave is detectable during infancy as early as four to six months, when the peak frequency the wave reaches can be as low as 5.4 [[Hertz|Hz]].<ref name=Nystrom /><ref name=Berchicci /> There is a rapid increase in peak frequency in the first year of life,<ref name=Berchicci>{{cite journal|last=Berchicci|first=M.|author2=Zhang, T. |author3=Romero, L. |author4=Peters, A. |author5=Annett, R. |author6=Teuscher, U. |author7=Bertollo, M. |author8=Okada, Y. |author9=Stephen, J. |author10= Comani, S. |title=Development of Mu Rhythm in Infants and Preschool Children|journal=Developmental Neuroscience|date=21 July 2011|volume=33|issue=2|pages=130–143|doi=10.1159/000329095|pmid=21778699|pmc=3221274}}</ref> and by age two frequency typically reaches 7.5 Hz.<ref name=Marshall /> The peak frequency of the mu wave increases with age until maturation into adulthood, when it reaches its final and stable frequency of 8–13 Hz.<ref name=Nystrom /><ref name=Marshall /><ref name=Berchicci /> These varying frequencies are measured as activity around the [[central sulcus]], within the Rolandic cortex.<ref name=Pineda3>{{cite journal|last=Pineda|first=Jaime A.|title=The functional significance of mu rhythms: Translating "seeing" and "hearing" into "doing" |journal=Brain Research Reviews |date=1 December 2005 |volume=50 |issue=1 |pages=57–68 |doi= 10.1016/j.brainresrev.2005.04.005|pmid=15925412}}</ref>
Mu waves are thought to be indicative of an infant’s developing ability to [[imitate]]. This is important because the ability to imitate plays a vital role in the development of [[motor skill]]s, tool use, and understanding causal information through social interaction.<ref name=Marshall /> Mimicking is integral in the development of social skills and understanding nonverbal cues.<ref name=Nystrom /> Causal relationships can be made through social learning without requiring experience firsthand. In action execution, mu waves are present in both infants and adults before and after the execution of a motor task and its accompanying desynchronization. While executing a goal-oriented action, however, infants exhibit a higher degree of desynchronization than do adults. Just as with an action execution, during action observation infants’ mu waves not only show a desynchronization, but show a desynchronization greater in degree than the one evidenced in adults.<ref name=Nystrom /> This tendency for changes in degree of desynchronization, rather than actual changes in frequency, becomes the measure for mu wave development throughout adulthood, although the most changes take place during the first year of life.<ref name=Berchicci /> Understanding the mechanisms that are shared between action perception and execution in the earliest years of life has implications for [[language development]]. Learning and understanding through social interaction comes from imitating movements as well as vowel sounds. Sharing the experience of attending to an object or event with another person can be a powerful force in the development of language.<ref name=Meltzoff>{{cite journal|last=Meltzoff|first=A. N. |author2=Kuhl, P. K. |author3=Movellan, J. |author4= Sejnowski, T. J. |title=Foundations for a New Science of Learning |journal=Science |date=17 July 2009 |volume=325 |issue=5938 |pages=284–288 |doi=10.1126/science.1175626 |pmid=19608908 |pmc=2776823}}</ref>
===Autism=== [[Autism]] is a disorder that is associated with social and communicative deficits. A single cause of autism has yet to be identified, but the mu wave and mirror neuron system have been studied specifically for their role in the disorder. In a typically developing individual, the mirror neuron system responds when he or she either watches someone perform a task or performs the task him- or herself. In individuals with autism, mirror neurons become active (and consequently mu waves are suppressed) only when the individual performs the task him- or herself.<ref name="Bernier"/><ref name=Oberman2>{{cite journal |last=Oberman |first=L.M. |author2=Pineda, J. A. |author3=Ramachandran, V.S. |title=The human mirror neuron system: A link between action observation and social skills |journal=Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience |year=2006 |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=62–66 |doi=10.1093/scan/nsl022 |pmc=2555434 |pmid=18985120}}</ref> This finding has led some scientists, notably [[Vilayanur S. Ramachandran|V. S. Ramachandran]] and colleagues, to view autism as disordered understanding of other individuals' [[intention]]s and [[goal]]s due to problems with the mirror neuron system.<ref name=Williams /> This deficiency would explain the difficulty people with autism have in communicating with and understanding others. While most studies of the mirror neuron system and mu waves in people with autism have focused on simple motor tasks, some scientists speculate that these tests can be expanded to show that problems with the mirror neuron system underlie overarching [[Cognitive deficit|cognitive]] and [[Social skills|social]] deficits.<ref name=Oberman /><ref name=Bernier />
Based on findings correlating mirror neuron activity and mu wave suppression in individuals with autism as in typically developing individuals,<ref name=Pineda2>{{cite journal |last=Pineda |first=J.A. |author2=Juavinett, A. |author3=Datko, M. |title=Self-regulation of brain oscillations as a treatment for aberrant brain connections in children with autism |journal=Medical Hypotheses |date=December 2012 |volume=79 |issue=6 |pages=790–798 |doi= 10.1016/j.mehy.2012.08.031 |pmid=22999736 }}</ref> studies have examined both the development of mirror neurons and therapeutic means for stimulating the system. A recent study has found that [[fMRI]] activation magnitudes in the [[inferior frontal gyrus]] increase with age in people with autism. This finding was not apparent in typically developing individuals. Furthermore, greater activation was associated with greater amounts of eye contact and better [[social functioning]].<ref name=Bastiaansen>{{cite journal |last=Bastiaansen |first=JA |author2=Thioux, M; Nanetti, L; van der Gaag, C; Ketelaars, C; Minderaa, R; Keysers, C |title=Age-related increase in inferior frontal gyrus activity and social functioning in autism spectrum disorder |journal= Biological Psychiatry |date=May 1, 2011 |volume=69 |issue=9 |pages=832–838 |pmid=21310395 |doi= 10.1016/j.biopsych.2010.11.007}}</ref> Scientists believe the inferior frontal gyrus is one of the main neural correlates with the mirror neuron system in humans and is often related to deficits associated with autism.<ref name=Keuken>{{cite journal |last=Keuken |first=M.C. |author2= Hardie, A.; Dorn, B. T.; Dev, S.; Paulus, M.P.; Jonas, K.J.; Den Wildenberg, W.P.; Pineda, J.A. |title=The role of the left inferior frontal gyrus in social perception: an rTMS study |journal=Brain Research |date=April 2011 |volume=1383 |pages=196–205 |pmid=21281612 |doi= 10.1016/j.brainres.2011.01.073}}</ref> These findings suggest that the mirror neuron system may not be non-functional in individuals with autism, but simply abnormal in its development. This information is significant to the present discussion because mu waves may be integrating different areas of mirror neuron activity in the brain.<ref name=Pineda3 /> Other studies have assessed attempts to consciously stimulate the mirror neuron system and suppress mu waves using [[neurofeedback]] (a type of [[biofeedback]] given through computers that analyze real time recordings of brain activity, in this case EEGs of mu waves). This type of therapy is still in its early phases of implementation for individuals with autism, and has conflicting forecasts for success.<ref name=Holtmann>{{cite journal |last=Holtmann |first=Martin |author2=Steiner, Sabina |author3=Hohmann, Sarah |author4=Poustka, Luise |author5= Banaschewski, Tobias |author6= Bölte, Sven |title=Neurofeedback in autism spectrum disorders |journal=Developmental Medicine & Child Neurology |date=November 2011 |origyear=14 July 2011 |volume=53 |issue=11 |pages=986–993 |doi= 10.1111/j.1469-8749.2011.04043.x |pmid=21752020 }}</ref><ref name=Coben>{{cite journal |last=Coben |first=Robert |author2=Linden, Michael |author3=Myers, Thomas E. |title=Neurofeedback for Autistic Spectrum Disorder: A Review of the Literature |journal=Applied Psychophysiology and Biofeedback |origyear=24 Oct 2009 |date=March 2010|volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=83–105 |doi= 10.1007/s10484-009-9117-y |pmid=19856096}}</ref>
==Brain-computer interfaces==
[[Brain-computer interface]]s (BCIs) are a developing technology that clinicians hope will one day bring more independence and agency to the severely physically disabled. Those the technology has the potential to help include people with near-total or total paralysis, such as those with [[tetraplegia]] (quadriplegia) or advanced [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS); BCIs are intended to help them to communicate or even move objects such as motorized wheelchairs, [[neuroprostheses]], or robotic grasping tools.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Machado>{{cite journal |last=Machado |first=S |author2= Araújo, F; Paes, F; Velasques, B; Cunha, M; Budde, H; Basile, LF; Anghinah, R; Arias-Carrión, O; Cagy, M; Piedade, R; de Graaf, TA; Sack, AT; Ribeiro, P |title=EEG-based brain-computer interfaces: an overview of basic concepts and clinical applications in neurorehabilitation |journal=Reviews in the neurosciences |year=2010 |volume=21 |issue=6 |pages=451–68 |pmid=21438193 |doi= 10.1515/REVNEURO.2010.21.6.451 }}</ref> Few of these technologies are currently in regular use by people with disabilities, but a diverse array are in development at an experimental level.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Pfurtscheller2>{{cite book |title=Brain-Computer Interfaces: Principles and Practice |year=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=9780195388855 |pages=227–240 |author= Pfurtscheller, Gert |author2=McFarland, Dennis J. |editor=Wolpaw, Jonathan R. |editor2=Wolpaw, Elizabeth Winter |chapter=BCIs that use sensorimotor rhythms}}</ref><ref name=Leuthardt>{{cite journal|last=Leuthardt|first=Eric C.|author2=Schalk, Gerwin |author3=Roland, Jarod |author4=Rouse, Adam |author5= Moran, Daniel W. |title=Evolution of brain-computer interfaces: going beyond classic motor physiology|journal=Neurosurgical Focus|year=2009|volume=27|issue=1|pages=E4|doi=10.3171/2009.4.FOCUS0979|pmc=2920041|pmid=19569892}}</ref> One type of BCI uses event-related desynchronization (ERD) of the mu wave in order to control the computer.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /> This method of monitoring brain activity takes advantage of the fact that when a group of neurons is at rest they tend to fire in synchrony with each other. When a participant is cued to imagine movement (an "event"), the resulting desynchronization (the group of neurons that was firing in synchronous waves now firing in complex and individualized patterns) can be reliably detected and analyzed by a computer. Users of such an interface are trained in visualizing movements, typically of the foot, hand, and/or tongue, which are each in different locations on the [[cortical homunculus]] and thus distinguishable by an [[electroencephalography|electroencephalograph]] (EEG) or [[electrocorticograph]] (ECoG) recording of electrical activity over the [[motor cortex]].<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Pfurtscheller2 /> In this method, computers monitor for a typical pattern of mu wave ERD [[contralateral]] to the visualized movement combined with event-related synchronization (ERS) in the surrounding tissue.<ref name=Pfurtscheller2 /> This paired pattern intensifies with training,<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Pfurtscheller2 /><ref name=Leuthardt /><ref name=Allison>{{cite journal |last=Allison |first=B Z |author2=Leeb, R |author3=Brunner, C |author4=Müller-Putz, G R |author5=Bauernfeind, G |author6=Kelly, J W |author7= Neuper, C |title=Toward smarter BCIs: extending BCIs through hybridization and intelligent control |journal=Journal of Neural Engineering |origyear=7 Dec 2011 |date=February 2012 |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=013001 |doi= 10.1088/1741-2560/9/1/013001 |pmid=22156029 }}</ref> and the training increasingly takes the form of games, some of which utilize [[virtual reality]].<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Pfurtscheller2 /><ref name=Allison /> Some researchers have found that the feedback from virtual reality games is particularly effective in giving the user tools to improve control of his or her mu wave patterns.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Allison /> The ERD method can be combined with one or more other methods of monitoring the brain's electrical activity to create hybrid BCIs, which often offer more flexibility than a BCI that uses any single monitoring method.<ref name=Pfurtscheller1 /><ref name=Pfurtscheller2 />
==History==
Mu waves have been studied since the 1930s, and are referred to as the wicket rhythm because the rounded EEG waves resemble [[Croquet|croquet wickets]]. In 1950, [[Henri Gastaut]] and his coworkers reported desynchronization of these waves not only during active movements of their subjects, but also while the subjects observed actions executed by someone else.<ref name=r1/><ref name=r2/> These results were later confirmed by additional research groups,<ref name="The blocking of the Rolandic wicket rhythm and some central changes related to movement">{{Cite journal |author1=Gian Emilio Chatrian |author2=Magnus C. Petersen |author3=Jorge A. Lazarte | title = The blocking of the Rolandic wicket rhythm and some central changes related to movement | journal = [[Electroencephalography and Clinical Neurophysiology]] | volume = 11 | issue = 3 | pages = 497–510 |date=August 1959
| doi = 10.1016/0013-4694(59)90048-3 | pmid = 13663823 }}</ref><ref name=r3/><ref name=r4/><ref name=r5/> including a study using [[wikt:subdural|subdural]] [[electrode]] grids in [[epileptic]] patients.<ref name=r6/> The latter study showed mu suppression while the patients observed moving body parts in [[Somatic nervous system|somatic]] areas of the cortex that corresponded to the body part moved by the actor. Further studies have shown that the mu waves can also be desynchronized by imagining actions<ref name=r7/><ref name=r8/> and by passively viewing point-light [[biological motion]].<ref name=r9/>
==See also==
===Brain waves=== * [[Delta wave]] – (0.1 – 3 Hz) * [[Theta wave]] – (4 – 7 Hz) * [[Alpha wave]] – (8 – 15 Hz){{citation needed|date=June 2015}} * Mu wave – (7.5 – 12.5 Hz){{citation needed|date=June 2015}} * [[Sensorimotor rhythm|SMR wave]] – (12.5 – 15.5 Hz) * [[Beta wave]] – (16 – 31 Hz) * [[Gamma wave]] – (32 – 100 Hz)

The ''Munay-Ki'' are a series of nine [[Empowerment (Vajrayana)|Empowerment]] [[rites]] based on the initiatory practices of the [[Q'ero]] shamans of Peru, as taught by anthropologist [[Alberto Villoldo]].<ref name="AC">''Williams, J.E.. The Andean Codex: Adventures and Initiations among the Peruvian Shamans'' (softcover); {{ISBN|978-1-571-74304-6}}</ref> "Munay" in [[Quechuan languages|Quechua]] means "love and will", together with "ki", from the Chinese word for energy, combine to give the meaning: energy of love.<ref name="WQE">''Parker, Phillip. Websters Quechua-English Thesaurus Dictionary'' (softcover); {{ISBN|978-0-497-83675-7}}</ref> The Munay-Ki is a modern form of transmitting the initiation empowerments of the Q'ero, and are based on the traditional initiation ceremonies of Q'ero shamans.<ref name="Ill">''Villoldo, Alberto. Illumination: The Shaman's Way of Healing'' (softcover); {{ISBN|978-1-401-92329-7}}</ref> Four Q'ero shamans have come to the United States several times to personally transmit the rites in the past six years, and many initiates have gone to Peru to receive the rites there. These shamans are held in high esteem by the members and trainees of The Four Winds Society.<ref name="EXP"> The Four Winds Society {{cite web |url=http://www.thefourwinds.com/expeditions |title=Expeditions and Retreats |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref>
==Origin== Villoldo learned and studied the rites of the [[Inca civilization|Inca]] [[Shamanism|Shamans]] with a number of mentors over a period of years living with them in the [[Andes]] Mountains of Peru.<ref name="origin">[http://www.munay-ki.org/Munay-Ki_The_Source_of_the_Rites.html Munay-Ki.org - Source of the Rites] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225233947/http://www.munay-ki.org/Munay-Ki_The_Source_of_the_Rites.html |date=2009-02-25 }}</ref> As he describes in his book Shaman Healer Sage,<ref name="SHS">''Villoldo, Alberto. Shaman, Healer, Sage: How to Heal Yourself and Others with the Energy Medicine of the Americas'' (hardcover); {{ISBN|978-0-609-60544-8}}</ref> he traveled for more than ten years with his first mentor Don Antonio Morales throughout the Andes and the Amazon to accumulate and distill the shamanic knowledge of these peoples. From this distilled knowledge of traditional shamanism, Dr. Villoldo gathered and assembled the Munay-Ki as a series of rites to initiate and empower students in their study and practice of shamanic healing.<ref name="origin" /> Some of the Munay-Ki rites are direct inclusions of traditional Q'ero initiatory rites: for example the Munay-Ki Day Keeper and Wisdom Keeper rites respectively are anglicized names for the Pampa Mesayok and Alto Mesayok karpay of the Q'ero.<ref name="MLE">''Wilcox, Joan. Masters of the Living Energy: The Mystical World of the Q'ero of Peru'' (softcover); {{ISBN|978-1-594-77012-8}} </ref> <ref name="video"> {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h-5KIhLDWIQ |title= Pampa Mesayok Transmission |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=YouTube |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2013}} </ref>
Villoldo writes that the rites derive from the great [[initiation]]s from the [[Indus Valley Civilization|Indus Valley]] that were brought to the Americas by the first [[Medicine Man|medicine men and women]] who crossed the [[Bering Strait]] from [[Siberia]] during the [[glacial period]] some 30,000 years ago, and who were known as the Laika, the Earthkeepers of old. <ref name="munay">[http://www.munay-ki.org/Munay-Ki_The_Heros_Journey.html Munay-ki.org - The Heroes Journey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124055618/http://munay-ki.org/Munay-Ki_The_Heros_Journey.html |date=2009-01-24 }}</ref>
==Purpose== The Munay-Ki rites are initiations intended to help the person receiving them to become a person of wisdom and power.<ref name="munay" /> Like the Q'ero initiations they include, the Munay-Ki are given at the beginning of one's shamanic training in order to guide the student successfully through their studies and development into a healer. <ref name="Ill" /> <ref name="WBW">''Kinch, Denise. Walk Between Worlds, Truth is Beauty, the Q'ero'' (softcover); {{ISBN|978-1-4415-3382-1}} </ref>
==Criticism== The authenticity of these rites are disputed however, and some argue that they are totally fabricated and have no relationship with the Q'ero nation. Critics argue that Dr. Villoldo has exploited the Q'ero nation with his teachings in order to make money. His Four Winds Society has become very popular in the United States, but is not without controversy. Some indigenous groups see this as a prime example of cultural appropriation, while followers believe that Dr. Villoldo was given permission by his teachers to share the teachings. This is a prime example of neoshamanism.

'''Myles McSweeney''' (1814-1881) was an Irish [[Chartism|Chartist]], mythologist and [[Secularism|secularist]] writer.
McSweeney was born in [[Northern Ireland]] but moved to London. He was influenced by the views of [[Robert Taylor (Radical)|Robert Taylor]] and wrote for the [[National Reformer]] and ''Secular Chronicle''.<ref>[[Joseph Mazzini Wheeler|Wheeler, Joseph Mazzini]]. (1889). ''A Biographical Dictionary of Freethinkers of All Ages and Nations''. London: Progressive Publishing Company. p. 215</ref>
He was a former [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] who became anti-Christian.<ref>Shipley, Stan. (1983). ''Club Life and Socialism in Mid-Victorian London''. Journeyman. p. 25</ref> Historian [[Steven Fielding (political historian)|Steven Fielding]] has described McSweeney as a "leading secularist lecturer in London's proletarian clubland."<ref>[[Steven Fielding (political historian)|Feilding, Steven]]. (1993). ''Class and Ethnicity: Irish Catholics in England, 1880-1939''. Open University Press. p. 109</ref>
McSweeney was an advocate of the [[Christ myth theory]] and lectured on the subject.<ref>[[Charles Maurice Davies|Davies, Charles Maurice]]. (1874). [https://archive.org/stream/heterodoxlondono01daviiala#page/111/mode/2up ''Heterodox London: Or, Phases of Free Thought in the Metropolis'']. London: Tinsley Brothers. pp. 111-120</ref> He was known for having reduced "Christ to a Solar Myth".<ref>Shipley, Stan. (1983). ''Club Life and Socialism in Mid-Victorian London''. Journeyman. p. 37. "Myles McSweeney was an old Chartist who could reduce 'Christ to a Solar Myth' in a 'quaint style' which club members knew and loved. When he died in 1881 subscriptions for his funeral were sent in from all over London."</ref> In the 1870s he associated with [[Charles Bradlaugh]].<ref>[[David James O'Donoghue|O'Donoghue, David James]]. (1912). [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924029566530#page/n305/mode/2up ''The Poets of Ireland: A Biographical and Bibliographical Dictionary of Irish Writers of English Verse'']. Dublin: Figgis & Co. p. 292</ref>
==Selected publications==
*''Two Visions: The Pope and Old Nick, The Pan-Anglican Synod and Bishop Colenso'' (1867) *''Moses and Bacchus: A Mythological Parallel'' (1874) *[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=_AWGVkJJRUYC&pg=RA1-PA79&dq=%22Buddhism+and+Christianity:+A+Parallel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjpvtfyw4_XAhVFfhoKHd7pArAQuwUIQTAF#v=onepage&q=%22Buddhism%20and%20Christianity%3A%20A%20Parallel%22&f=false ''Buddhism and Christianity: A Parallel''] (1876)

''Pitcher'' }} The '''Pakistan National Congress''' (PNC), later known as the '''Bangladesh National Congress''', was a political party that mainly represented the [[Hindu]]s and other religious minorities in [[Pakistan]].{{cite book|title=Major governments of Asia|author=George McTurnan Kahin, Harold C. Hinton|publisher=[[Cornell University]] Press|pages=439|year=1958|isbn=}}{{cite book|title=Worldmark Encyclopedia of the Nations: Asia and Australasia|author=Moshe Y. Sachs|publisher=Worldmark Press|pages=|year=1967}} The party championed [[secularism]] in the Muslim-dominated state, and its electoral and organisational strength was mainly based in [[East Bengal]] (also known as [[East Pakistan]], now the independent state of [[Bangladesh]]).{{cite book|title=War and Secession: Pakistan, India and the Creation of Bangladesh|author=Richard Sisson, Leo E. Rose|publisher=University of California Press|pages=1–15|year=1991|isbn=978-0-520-07665-5}} ==Background== The Pakistan National Congress traces its roots to the [[Indian National Congress]], which was the largest national political party in India. The Indian National Congress, led by [[Mahatma Gandhi]], [[Vallabhbhai Patel]] and [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] championed secularism, religious tolerance and opposed the [[Pakistan movement]] led by the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]]. However, ensuing communal conflict led to the partition of India and the creation of Pakistan from Muslim-majority provinces. The religious violence and mass migration as a result of partition significantly reduced the Hindu, Sikh and non-Muslim population of Pakistan. The leaders and activists of the Indian National Congress who continued to live in Pakistan joined with the representatives of Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist and Christian communities to form a new political party, the Pakistan National Congress. Although most of them had opposed partition, the members of the new party accepted the state of Pakistan and did not maintain any organisational links with the Indian National Congress. ==Positions== The Pakistan National Congress stood for secularism, equality of all religions and citizens and protection of religious and ethnic minorities. The party sought peaceful and friendly relations between Pakistan and India. The party was one of many that opposed the suppression of democracy and civil rights by successive military regimes. The Pakistan National Congress also stood against the growth of Islamic fundamentalism in Pakistani society, politics and government. The party also supported the [[Bengali language movement]] in East Bengal. ===Bengali Language Movement=== {{main|Role of political parties during Bengali Language Movement}} National Congress was the only party at the opposition side of the house during the movement. In both Legislative Assembly and in [[Constituent Assembly of Pakistan|Constituent Assembly]] they exposed of the logical position of the language demand. In doing so some of the members were called Indian agents and were harassed by the government. Some leaders were also arrested and one of them was killed inside the jail.{{Harv|Umar|1979|p=617}} ==Electoral Performance== While partition riots and mass migration had significantly reduced the Hindu and Sikh population in West Pakistan, Hindus still constituted twenty percent of the population of East Bengal (also East Pakistan). Consequently, the PNC's base and organisation were concentrated in that province of Pakistan. In the [[East Bengali legislative election, 1954|1954 elections]] held for the East Bengal Legislative Assembly, the Pakistan National Congress won 28 seats. ==Bangladesh== After the [[Bangladeshi War of Independence]], the party briefly survived as the Bangladesh National Congress ({{lang-bn|বাংলাদেশ জাতীয় কংগ্রেস}} ''Bangladesh Jatiya Congress'').February 25, 1975, [[The Daily Ittefaq]] on Tuesday The party stood one candidate, Sree Peter Paul Gomez in the [[Bangladeshi general election, 1973|1973 election]] for Dacca-25,http://www.ecs.gov.bd/English/PrintElection.php?&electionid=1&party=13&PartyName=Bagladesh%20Jatiya%20Congress&id=partywise but did not win the seat. The party was dissolved in 1975 after the formation of the [[Bangladesh Krishak Sramik Awami League]] as the sole political party of Bangladesh. It is unknown how long the party survived in [[West Pakistan]].http://en.sachalayatan.com/statuses/615 ==(Incomplete) List of Congress members in the 1st Constituent Assembly== ===East Bengal=== #[[Prem Hari Barma]] #[[Raj Kumar Chakraverty]] #[[Sris Chandra Chattopadhyaya]] #[[Akhay Kumar Das]] #[[Dhirendra Nath Datta]] #[[Bhupendra Kumar Datta]] #[[Jnanendra Chandra Majumdar]] #[[Birat Chandra Mandal]] #[[Sri Dhananjoy M.A. B.L. Roy]] #[[Maudi Bhakesh Chanda]] #[[Harendra Kumar Sur]] #[[Kawivi Kerwar Datta]] ===West Punjab=== #[[Ganga Saran]], Rai Bahadur Lala == See also == * [[Indian Union Muslim League]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Socialist parties in Pakistan]] [[Category:Hinduism in Pakistan]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Pakistan]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Pakistan]] [[Category:Secularism in Pakistan]]

The '''Nayak''' is a [[Suryavanshi Rajput]]<ref>''People of India'', Volume II, edited by K.S Singh. P.964</ref> clan found in the state of [[Rajasthan]], [[Gujarat]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Orisa]], [[Punjab]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Karnataka]] in India. The word Nayak means a head of a regiment. This word is derived from the [[Sanskrit]] Sena Nayak, which means "head of a regiment". The Nayak traces their origin back to [[Suryavani Rajput]].<ref name="poi">''People of India'', Volume II, edited by K.S Singh.</ref> Nayak is not same or similar to Naik or Nayaka castes. Nayak is separate from Naik or Nayaka castes. ==History and origin== Nayak word is derived from the [[Sanskrit]] word Sena Nayak, which means the leader or head of a regiment. The Nayak trace their origin back to [[Suryavanshi Rajputs]] or [[Rajanya Kayasthas]]. They claim that they used to hold the rank of Nayak in Royal Forces. They were highly regarded for their bravery, in due course they became a powerful group and occupied several forts and jagirs. In fear of their growing power the rulers tried to defame them in various ways. Then Nayak withdrew themselves from the association of the [[Suryavanshi Rajputs]] or [[Rajanya Kayasthas]] and came out as a separate community. It is said that when [[Parashuram]] the great mythical character was killing the [[Kshatriyas]] then the Nayak had to conceal their Kshatriya identity. Rajanya is the real word for kshatriyas according to Rig-Veda Purush Sukta. They have several other legends in which they trace their ancestry back to the mythical characters of lnchhbasu. One of the five sons of [[Surya]] to one of the wives of [[Brihaspati]] who was impregnated by [[Chandrama]] to Sangnya, One of the three wives of Surya. They recall their origin at Jatala village whence they migrated to [[Jaisalmer]] and hence to the various other parts. They are distributed in the districts of [[Sri Ganganagar]], [[Churu]], [[Sikar]], [[Nagaur]], [[Jhunjhunu]] etc. Their spoken language is [[Marwari language|Marwari]]. They are conversant with [[Hindi]], Script used is [[Devnagari]]. The Nayak have the two divisions of nakh and dudh (clan). There are altogether sixteen nakhs namely Panwar, Solanki, Chauhan, Chalukya, Bhati, Tanwar, Rang-ghad, Bagla, Chandela, Dhol, Sodath, Khinchi, Ran, Gor, Galhot and Rathore. Each of the nakh has a number of dudh in it. Bhati have nine dudh. Panwar have seven. Tanwar includes eight. Rathore have nine dudhs. Dudh are namely Malkhot, Potwana, Dhulkia, Kayat, Bokra, Dagla, Sudia, Chanwaria, Chandalia, Boyat, Rojh, Ghoran, Barwasa, Banyal, Goglia, Chaaran, Saarsar, Gagrhia, Arhia etc. Concept of hierarchy is not associated with these divisions. In the traditional varna order they are ranked as Kshatriya. Community endogamy and nakh and dudh exogamy are the rule. Junior levirate is allowed. Child marriage has been replaced by post-puberty marriage. Selection of match is ﬁnalised with the performance sagai (betrothal). Marriage is solemnized at bride's place. The bride and the groom take phera (circulations of sacred ﬁre). Garuda Brahman performs the job of priest. A feast is arranged by the bride's parents. The consummation of marriage is held at groom's house. Monogamy is the prevalent practice. Polygamy is permissible in case of barrenness of the wife. Bora (toe ring), aonla and pajeb (silver anklet) are the marriage symbols for women. Bride price is paid in cash and in kind. Post-marital residence is patrilocal. Divorce is permitted. Either the spouses can initiate its proceedings. Remarriage is allowed for widow, widower and divorcee. Remarriage of a woman is called nata consisting of only a bief formality. However in case a widower is marrying an unmarried girl than the marriage is solemnised with phera and in detail. The prevalent type of family is extended type followed by nuclear family. The male member holds the authority and decision-making power. In a family the relation between father-in-law and daughter-in-law and that between brother-in-law (husband's elder brother) and sister-in-law (younger brother's wife) is of avoidance. Joking relations exist between elder brother's wife and husband's younger brother and also among elder sister's husband and wife's younger sister. Property is inherited in the male line and male equigeniture is the norm. Authority succeeds from father to the eldest son. Inter-family linkages among the community people are maintained through mutual help and cooperation.
The women in normal circumstances do not go out for earning. Household work and looking after the children is their main responsibility. They participate in social and religious activities but have no role in socio-political organization of the community. They bring potable water, collect ﬁrewood, in family as well as in society women are subordinate to men. After delivery. sutak (pollution period) is observed for soa-mahina(five weeks) during which the mother and the baby are kept conﬁned in a room. The pollution period for the family members end with suraj pujan. Name of the child is selected on that day. After five weeks jarhula (tonsure) is done in case of male child. Among the Nayak dead are cremated. The corpse is taken to the samsan (crematorium) on arthi (wooden bier). The widow of the deceased gives up her marriage symbols on the arthi. The corpse is placed on the pyre with its head to the east. Eldest son acts as chief mourner, who lights the pyre. On the third day unburnt bones and ashes are collected which are disposed of at Haridwar. Sutak (death pollution) is observed for twelve days which ends with kriya (death rites). The funeral feast arranged on this day is attended by kins and caste men. The succession rites are performed for the eldest son in the evening. The Nayak by religion are Hindu. Pabuji is their main deity. He is believed to be the incarnation of God. They also worship Gogaji, Ramdevji, Shivji, Kalka (Kali) mata, Nagechi Mate, Bheruji, Karni mata etc. They have kula devi (lineage goddess). Besides, Nagechi is their community goddess. They go to pilgrimage to Runecha (Jaisalmer), Gangaji at Haridwar etc. Gauda Brahman acts as sacred specialist in their life cycle rituals. Holi, Deepavali, Rakshabandhan, Gangaur etc. are their major festivals. The community have the oral tradition of songs and tales. During festivals and in marriage women sing folk songs. The Nayak have traditional linkages with Garuda Brahmans, Dholi, Nai, who offer them priestly and other specialized services. They accept water and cooked food from the all the clean castes and vice versa. But do not accept the same from Sansi, Meghwal, etc. Putative kinship is maintained with whom they have commensal relations. They share water source with other communities in the locality. They have access to schools, temples etc. They use both traditional and modern medicare system. They have favorable attitude towards family planning. Hand pump and tap water are their sources of drinking water.<ref>''People of India'', Volume II, edited by K.S Singh.P.964</ref>
